The problems with calling overridden methods in a constructor are=

particularly nasty when it comes to inner classes - and *very* nasty
for a=
nonymous inner classes which use variables in the declaring method.

There =
was a change to the Java compiler (and the byte code spec, if I
remember co=
rrectly) to allow certain fields to be initialised *before*
the call to the=
 superconstructor - fields such as those effectively
taken from the declari=
ng method for anonymous inner classes, and the
hidden field containing the =
reference to the "parent" instance for all
inner classes.

Now, I can't fin=
d where the change is documented unfortunately - I
thought it was a feature=
 in 1.4, but I can't see it in the release
notes. Anyway, I suspect that we=
'll find the OP was using an older
version of javac than I am, hence the di=
fference.

In the light of this, I would after all agree with the idea that=
 using
an overridden method in a constructor puts you in no man's land, at
=
least in the case where you're using an inner class.
